Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 11:55AM kennessee wrote: Hi!  I am 27 and have lumpy boobs too.  It's hard not to stress when there is family history.  I know my grandmother had it and I think her mother too.  None of my aunts have it so far.  I had 3 lumps removed in May of last year and they were all benign.  Right now, I have a couple lumps in each breast and will be getting checked out again.  I can't offer any advice about the nipple discharge.  But, I just wanted to chime in and let you know that I have had lumps that have turned out to be benign and I am hoping yours will as well.  Please keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Worried Newbie NJLee NJLee

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 02:10PM kennessee wrote: Hey JamJam!  I'm 27 with numerous lumps in both breasts.  I am being told to "watch and see" and every doctor I visit I hear that " It's probably not cancer- you're so young!" I have asked for biopsies of the lumps b/c 1. it's my health and I should get to make that decision 2. I have two young children that I want to be around for and 3.  I have family history of BC!  I know I'm young.  I know the odds are in my favor.   But I'm not a risk taker.  There was a girl from my hometown who was diagnosed at 24 and died at 29 from breast cancer.  It happens to women of all ages.     So I just try to educate myself about it.  I've had some of my lumps for a year and a half and to me, from my touch, some have grown.... yet, they are still "waiting and watching" before they will biopsy anything.  In August, I had a Dr. tell me, just by feeling my lumps, that they don't feel like anything cancerous so no need to biopsy.  It just adds to my stress, unfortunately.  I'm kind of used to hearing " You're so young".
Posts.Title: Anyone told they're too young? jamjam29 kennessee

Posts.Content: kennessee wrote: Hello!  I am a 26 year old military wife and mother to two.  I recently found, on accident, two lumps in my left breast.  The first lump I found is the size of a pea, hard and it moves.  The second lump I actually had to look for.  It's a little deeper in the breast.  I have to push down deep in the tissue to find it.  If I didn't find that first lump I never would have found the second.  I have never checked my breasts before and I was tanning and arranged my boobs and that's when I found it!  The second lump is the size of two of my fingertips, hard, oval and it moves as well.  I am trying so hard not to freak right now, but with my husband deployed and being a stay at home mom I have a lot of time on my hands to browse the internet!  Also, my great grandmother and grandmother both had breast cancer ( maternal side ).  My mom is going through this right now as well.  She has a lot of lumps and has to get more testing done after a mammogram.  So, my mom could possibly have breast cancer.  I have made an appt to get seen with a doctor but it's not till April 27th.  I am worried that they will take one look at my age and dismiss anything I say, including family history.  It's happened to me before and I just don't trust doctors anymore.  I have also read that on younger women mammos and u/s sometimes don't show anything.  If that happens ( I know I'm thinking way ahead b/c doctors never listen to me ) do I have the right to get them biopsied?? Thanks so much!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Two lumps in the same breast kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 03:33PM kennessee wrote: Thank you all!  I think it is probably fibroadenomas but I can't stop the nagging in my head... which I think is just the "what if's" b/c of the strong family history.  I love this website and I will keep ya'll updated on what I find out and what my mom finds out.  I would suggest this site to my mother but she doesn't really understand the whole internet thing.
Posts.Title: Two lumps in the same breast kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 04:39PM kennessee wrote: Well I went to my doctor today and she felt both lumps that I have.  She did a full breast exam on me and said she felt something in my right too.  She ordered a diagnostic mammo and u/s.  I have to call and schedule that tomorrow.  She said to tell them it's important and to get me in asap.  That has me a little worried honestly.  I've read all these stories about everyone having to wait and wait and now the doctor wants me to get seen asap??  Would she have been able to feel anything that would make her want to put a rush on things?
Posts.Title: Two lumps in the same breast kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 07:27PM kennessee wrote: Alligans, Yes, I am going to get the biopsy.  I'm glad that my PCP suggested it b/c of the family history.  My gut is telling me benign but it's better to play it safe and have a biopsy back up the u/s report.
Posts.Title: A little update and question kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 07:56PM kennessee wrote: Yes, he's a breast surgeon... certified I should say.  He does most of his surgeries in bariatric care.  Lap-Bands, etc.
Posts.Title: Ultrasound today kennessee alligans

Posts.Content: kennessee wrote: I received the results from my u/s today.  The findings read: In the right breast at the 12 o'clock position is a well-defined hypoechoic, ovoid, solid mass that measures 7x4x5mm.  Similar lesion is seen in the left breast at the 2 o'clock position measuring 11x4x8mm.  There is a 3rd hypoechoic lesion that is also well-defined and oval shape in the left breast at the 3 o'clock position measuring 14x6x18mm.  No cystic masses are seen.  There is no duct dilatation or architectural distortion.  There is no skin thickening.  Impression: Solid masses in both breasts are benign in appearance and probably represent fibroadenomas.  Any decision to biopsy a palpable mass should be based on clinical suspicion.  Can anyone tell me how big these masses are b/c I am not good at math or conversions.  What does hypoechoic mean?  My PCP did give me a referral for a biopsy based on family history.  I will find out when that appt is hopefully within the next week.  So far, the lumps sound benign.  Hopefully the biopsy will confirm that.   I want to thank you all for the support on this forum.  I don't think any of my friends get how stressful it is to find something foreign in your body and how scary it is when there's also a family history involved.  Thanks so much!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A little update and question kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: kennessee wrote: I had a 6 month follow up today for a couple lumps that were under my areola region on my right breast.  I left feeling stressed out.  I have at least 5 or more pebble size lumps under the areola on my right breast!  I also have a larger lump on my left breast which he said looked like a fibroadenoma.  He said he wasn't concerned about any of the lumps since he removed 3 fibroadenomas last March.  I am not concerned about the large lump because it does resemble a fibroadenoma on the ultrasound... granted I'm not trained in sonography!  I'm more concerned about the cluster of pebble sized lumps under the areola.  He didn't want to biopsy ( this doctor pretty much only wants to do excisional/surgery! ) So I asked him couldn't he just do a needle biopsy since I tend to get these fibroadenomas a lot so I wouldn't have multiple scars/scar tissue.  He said to come back in 6 months to check the size and he didn't think it looked like they would need biopsied.  He said he was sure they were fibroadenomas.  I want to get a second opinion but I don't want them to think I'm a hypochondriac.  He told me I have so many fibroadenomas because I'm skinny?  Is that a true fact or no?  What should I do?  Should I be concerned that I have a lot of lumps under my nipple/areola area?  And another thing that irks me is that this appointment was for him to check the size of the lump that I found last time and see if it had grown.  He didn't even tell me if it had!  I'm so frustrated and stressed out right now.  On top of my breast issues, I have to see a gyno for a possible polyp on my cervix and it's taking me since December to be seen!  I had irregular bleeding in December and couldn't get seen till February.  Ridiculous.  And I'm dealing with all this and  going through a deployment.   Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Ultrasound today kennessee alligans

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 10:10PM kennessee wrote: Alligans- Sorry, I went back and re-read what I wrote.  I must have been typing faster than what my mind was thinking. Anyway, he asked if I felt any new lumps and I told him that I found a new lump but it's so hard to tell if it's a lump or if it was scar tissue from my past biopsy.  I had said that it's hard to tell with my breasts because everything feels lumpy to me.  He said everything feels lumpy because i'm skinny... not that i get fibroadenomas because i'm skinny.  Just wanted to clarify.  I've never cared much for this doctor because I always feel like I don't ever get answers or that my concerns are validated.  I'm 26 so I feel that my concerns do get brushed off quite often.  I asked him what are the options for a young woman who has dense breast tissue and frequent fibroadenomas and all he said to me was that it was frustrating to all of us-especially me ( me, not him ).  But he never did answer my question.   You said you've read a lot about fibroadenomas.  Why do some women get them so often?
Posts.Title: Ultrasound today kennessee alligans

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 11:23AM kennessee wrote: Thanks, mdoak, for taking the time to address my questions! Honestly, I am not sure why the surgeon did an excisional.  My PCM was the one who decided that they should be biopsied and the surgeon didn't let me know of any other biopsies.  I knew that he could have did a needle biopsy but his mind was set on excisional.  After reading these boards, I think I will ask for all my medical records just so I can have them handy.  I like to know what's going on and I feel like the records will explain things more to me than the surgeon has.  My last appt with him I had found a new lump and he did an u/s for about 30 secs and said everything looked fine.  Sometimes I feel like my worries are dismissed because I am so young.
Posts.Title: Multiple lumps and past fibroadenomas kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 09:15AM kennessee wrote: Meme-  I think I know what you are feeling.  My right breast is the same way.  I have tons of lumps, 4 fibroadenomas removed, and am 27 yrs. old.  At the top of my right breast, I have what feels like a gritty, gravelly area.  Don't know if it's a lump or tissue.  Or if it's tissue w/ lumps in it!  No clue.  I have had an ultrasound of that area and they saw a lump so no clue what to think right now.  Going down from that gritty area, it's like i have a string of lumps ( imagine a pearl necklace, if you will ).  It's like they are all connected and running vertically from that gritty area until it ends ( as far as I can tell ) under my nipple.  I don't know if that gritty area is thickening.  No clue what thickening is or what it feels like, if it's external or internal, etc.  I don't get nipple discharge however my nipples are extremely sensitive - all the time.   I don't have that gritty area in my left breast.  I have a couple lumps in that breast and from the last ultrasound it said I had mild subareolar ductal ectasia in the right breast.  Not sure if that's what all the little connected lumps are as nothing is ever explained to me.  Meme, do you get brushed off about this because of your age?  It happens to me a lot and I've been to 3 surgeons who dismiss me b/c of my age and previous fibroadenoma biopsies.  I hope your midwife listens to your concerns and gives you the testing you need to figure out what is going on with you.  I don't stand up for myself a lot when I go to the dr's so I am usually told to come back in 6 months which then repeats the come back in 6 months cycle - and I ask for a biopsy of the lumps I am concerned with every time.  Please update when you know more.
Posts.Title: Ridge of bumps meme31 meme31

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2011 05:33PM kennessee wrote: Sherri,  Thanks for letting us know about the string of pearls/Classic Lobular info.  I am 27 and have had my right breast monitored since March-ish of 2010.  Around that time, I had 4 fibroadenomas removed from my left breast.  They assumed that is what I had in my right breast.  I have noticed changes in my the R breast.  The top upper inner/middle part feels like a layer of swiss cheese.  Then starting at that swiss cheese, going downwards ( vertically in my breast ) I have a bunch of little lumps that feel like the string of pearls.  They keep telling me to come back and I ask for a biopsy every time which they don't want to do.  The radiologist says it's "probably fibroadenomas"  or they say fibrocystic breasts.  I have no pain in the breast.   I have another ultrasound in November.  I am usually never taken very seriously when I ask for biopsies b/c of previous fibroadenoma history and my age.  I hear "you're too young" at every appointment.  Should I ask for a MRI or keep pushing for a core biopsy?  I just want a firm diagnosis of a fibroadenoma if that is what they think it is.  I am not fond of "probably and most likely".
Posts.Title: Ridge of bumps meme31 meme31

Posts.Content: kennessee wrote: Hello ladies!  So after weeks of waiting, I have a consultation w/ a surgeon tomorrow morning.  I have 3 palpable lumps ( 2 in left breast, 1 in right ).  What exactly should I be expecting tomorrow?  Will the surgeon just look at my reports and decide what kind of biopsy he wants to do?  I was kind of bummed because I was expecting to go get the biopsies done. Then when I called to ask what procedure they were going to use to do the biopsies, I was told that it was just a consult.  I don't know how much more of this waiting I can take.  I'm so stressed out.  I have no support here.  My husband is deployed.  My kids are young and full of energy.  I'm exhausted.  My family is 10 hours away and I have no real friends here.  No one seems to care about my "issues" b/c they have their own stuff going on.  It's unfair to vent to my husband b/c he's in a war zone.  I'm glad that I found this board and I can get it out here. :) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Consultation w/ surgeon kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 09:55PM kennessee wrote: Yes, I definitely do not want anymore excisionals done.  The hard part for me is to even get them to agree to do a biopsy.  They use my age as a "statistic" and say it's nothing to worry about, etc. I just don't like knowing I have these in my breast without knowing 100% that they are benign.  I have two children to worry about and I don't want to be neglectful of my health.  If it is something, I'd want to find out early instead of waiting.  I am pretty confident that my breasts are just lumpy but I always have that nagging feeling.  There is a family history of BC as well as other cancers on the maternal side.   Thank you for your reply.  I'm very grateful for this board and the information I gather from it.  I think my family is tired of hearing me talk about my breasts every 6 months.

Posts.Content: May 15, 2011 10:40AM kennessee wrote: Thank you, Aug!  I wish it was easy to get them all biopsied.  I always have that little nagging voice in the back of my mind when I leave the lumps without being biopsied.  Because, yes it's rare for a young woman to get bc, but what if one of the lumps did fall in the 20%. I am seen every 6 months so I would hope that if any lumps change or grow they would biopsy ( however one of my lumps that has been in my right breast for a year has grown and they still didn't want to biopsy.. )
Posts.Title: What are the odds of 6 lumps being benign? kennessee Laleesa

Posts.Content: May 12, 2011 06:01PM kennessee wrote: I went to the surgeon today.  He didn't want to biopsy anything.  I told him that I was comfortable with most of my lumps because at this point I know what feels like a fibroadenoma.  There were 2 that I did not feel comfortable just leaving though.  And he agreed to biopsy those-- even though I had to fight for it which was very discouraging.  I usually try to avoid confrontations and arguments but I know my body and these 2 specific lumps do not feel like the rest.  1 lump under my areola region has been there since last year and it feels much bigger.  The other lump feels very ridgy/gritty.. like a fossil.  The person who did the ultrasound didn't even know what it was.. whether it was a lump or tissue.  I don't feel comfortable just leaving that one alone.  My husband is deployed right now and was a bit angry that I have to do this alone and that I am brushed off a lot.  I came home and called my best friend  and she was just clearly uninterested in hearing anything.  It was pretty hurtful as she has no idea why I am upset that I have to fight for biopsies and she had no interest in even listening to me vent... just wanted to talk about her recent purchases.  The only support system I have is my husband, who I can't even lean on right now, and this board.  Thank you all so much for allowing us confused and worried women here to ask questions and vent.  I am very grateful and your replies have really calmed most of my worries.
Posts.Title: What are the odds of 6 lumps being benign? kennessee Laleesa

Posts.Content: kennessee wrote: I am 27 years old. I had an ultrasound yesterday to get a look at all the lumps I have. I have 3 lumps in each breast.  Last year I had 3 fibroadenomas excisionally removed.  I am hoping that you ladies will be able to help me relieve my anxiety.   What are the chances that all 6 lumps will be benign fibroadenomas?  Why do I keep getting so many fibroadenomas?!  I feel like I have a bomb waiting to explode attached to my chest!  I am so tired ( emotionally and mentally ) of going in every 6 months, they give an ultrasound, say it's looks benign and don't even suggest a biopsy.   Is this what I have to look forward to for many more years?   I guess I don't really know what I'm asking with this post...  just some reassuring and encouraging words.  Is there anyone else on this board who has dealt with numerous lumps that all turned out benign??    Log in to post a reply

" U/S of the left breast demonstrates a small smooth walled nodule at 3 oclock beneath the areola measuring 0.80x0.59x0.94cm. Posts.Content: kennessee wrote: Hello!  I posted awhile back when I found a couple lumps in one breast.  I had an excisional biopsy on those and had the results right after waking up from the anesthesia... B9 fibroadenomas.  I'm back here posting because I have a couple questions.  I have found a new lump in the breast that I had the biopsies in and also I have a lump under my nipple on the opposite breast.  I am constantly finding new lumps.  It's starting to stress me out and cause a bit of anxiety.  My maternal grandmother had breast cancer  and I know the odds for me, being only 26, are slim that I would have it.  I also know that 80% of lumps are benign.   I have an appt Feb. 8 with the surgeon who did my biopsies to do ultrasound of my breast ( the lump under my nipple ) to see if it has grown.  Now, my questions:  Would a surgeon be able to read the ultrasound or should I get a referral to a radiologist to get the ultrasounds done?  Also, with women who constantly have lumps in their boobs, what should the course of action be?  Will I have to get an ultrasound every so many months to monitor them?  What are my the other types of biopsies that can be performed besides excisional?  Last question... is there a link between cervical and breast cancer?  I have an appt with a gyno coming up as well since an urgent care dr found a something that looked like a polyp.  I haven't had a pap in 2 years.  My husband is military and we moved right around the time my pap was due and eventually life got in the way and I forgot all about it.   Thanks for reading and hopefully you ladies can help answer some of my questions that I can't seem to find the answers to anywhere else.    Log in to post a reply
